label: thm-mean-field-equation
title: The Mean-Field Equations for the Euclidean Gas
nl_statement: The evolution of the Euclidean Gas in the mean-field limit is governed by a coupled system of equations for the alive density $f(t,z)$ and the dead mass $m_d(t)$, subject to specified initial conditions.

equations.label: eq-mean-field-pde-main
equations.latex: \partial_t f = L^\dagger f - c(z)f + B[f, m_d] + S[f]

\partial_t f(t,z) = -
abla\cdot(A(z) f(t,z)) + 
abla\cdot(\mathsf{D}
abla f(t,z)) - c(z)f(t,z) + \lambda_{	ext{revive}} m_d(t)  rac{f(t,z)}{m_a(t)} + S[f](t,z)

hypotheses.text: Initial condition for the alive density: $f(0, \cdot) = f_0$
Initial condition for the dead mass: $m_d(0) = 1 - \int_\Omega f_0$

conclusion.text: The evolution of the Euclidean Gas in the mean-field limit is governed by the coupled system involving the alive density $f(t,z)$ and the dead mass $m_d(t)$.

constraints: zero in interior, positive near boundary

implicit_assumptions.text: The kinetic transport operators defining $L^\dagger$ involve diffusion and drift.
The domain of the gas is $\Omega$.
The revival operator $B[f, m_d]$ is sometimes written explicitly using $\lambda_{\text{revive}}$.

label: thm-mass-conservation
title: Total Mass Conservation and Population Dynamics
nl_statement: Any sufficiently regular solution $(f(t,z), m_d(t))$ to the Mean-Field Equations conserves total population mass and has an alive population mass evolution governed by revival and killing rates.

hypotheses.text: Sufficiently regular solution $(f(t,z), m_d(t))$ to the Mean-Field Equations.

conclusion.text: The total population $m_a(t) + m_d(t)$ is conserved for all time $t>0$, and the alive mass $m_a(t)$ evolves according to $\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}t}m_a(t) = \lambda_{\text{rev}} m_d(t) - k_{\text{killed}}[f](t)$.

variables.role: total killing rate dependent on f

implicit_assumptions.text: The system evolves according to the Mean-Field Equations.
The initial condition is such that $m_a(0) + m_d(0) = 1$ if conservation is to imply $m_a(t) + m_d(t) = 1$.

label: thm-killing-rate-consistency
title: Consistency of the Interior Killing Rate Approximation
nl_statement: Under specified regularity assumptions, the limit of the scaled discrete exit probability equals a smooth killing rate $c(x,v)$, and the scaled expected killing fraction converges to the continuous expected killing rate, with a specified error bound involving $\tau$ and the difference between discrete and continuous densities.

conclusion.text: There exists a smooth killing rate function $c \in C^\infty_c(\Omega)$ with compact support in $\mathcal{T}_\delta$ such that: (i) $\lim_{\tau \to 0} \frac{1}{\tau} p_{\text{exit}}(x,v,\tau) = c(x,v)$, and (ii) $\lim_{\tau \to 0} \frac{1}{\tau} K_{\text{discrete}}(\tau) = K_{\text{continuous}}$ with the error bound $\left|\frac{1}{\tau} K_{\text{discrete}}(\tau) - K_{\text{continuous}}\right| \le C \left(\sqrt{\tau} + \|f^\tau - f\|_{L^1}\right)$.
conclusion.latex: c \in C^\infty_c(\Omega) \text{ exists s.t. } \lim_{\tau \to 0} \frac{1}{\tau} p_{\text{exit}}(x,v,\tau) = c(x,v) \text{ and } \lim_{\tau \to 0} \frac{1}{\tau} K_{\text{discrete}}(\tau) = K_{\text{continuous}}

variables.role: expected killing fraction in discrete timestep

implicit_assumptions.text: The existence of a smooth killing rate function $c \in C^\infty_c(\Omega)$ implies appropriate smoothness and decay properties for the underlying geometry and dynamics.

label: thm-mean-field-limit-informal
title: Mean-Field Limit (Informal Statement)
nl_statement: The empirical density $f_N^\tau(t, x, v)$ of the $N$-particle discrete Fragile Gas dynamics converges weakly to some limiting density $f(t, x, v)$ under the joint limit $N \to \infty, \tau \to 0$ with $\tau = O(N^{-\alpha})$ for $\alpha > 0$.

equations.latex: f_N^\tau(t, x, v) := \frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^N \delta(x - X_i^\tau(t), v - V_i^\tau(t))

hypotheses.text: Let $(X_i^\tau(t), V_i^\tau(t))_{i=1}^N$ be the $N$-particle discrete Fragile Gas dynamics with timestep $\tau$.
The limit is taken as $N \to \infty, \tau \to 0$ with $\tau = O(N^{-\alpha})$ for $\alpha > 0$.

conclusion.text: The empirical density $f_N^\tau(t, \cdot, \cdot)$ converges weakly to $f(t, \cdot, \cdot)$.

implicit_assumptions.text: The weak convergence is implicitly meant in a suitable space, likely involving $L^p$ spaces or measures.
